segment.source: Drive Partition Rules
segment.target: Drive Partition Rules

segment.source: When you deploy Windows to a UEFI-based device, you must format the hard drive that includes the Windows partition by using a GUID partition table (GPT) file system.
segment.target: When you deploy Windows to a UEFI-based device, you must format the hard drive that includes the Windows partition by using a GUID partition table (GPT) file system.

segment.source: Additional drives may use either the GPT or the master boot record (MBR) file format.
segment.target: Additional drives may use either the GPT or the master boot record (MBR) file format.

segment.source: A GPT drive may have up to 128 partitions.
segment.target: A GPT drive may have up to 128 partitions.

segment.source: Each partition can have a maximum of 18 exabytes (~18.8 million terabytes) of space.
segment.target: Each partition can have a maximum of 18 exabytes (~18.8 million terabytes) of space.

segment.source: Windows partition requirements:
segment.target: Windows partition requirements:

segment.source: System partition
segment.target: System partition

segment.source: The device must contain a system partition.
segment.target: The device must contain a system partition.

segment.source: On GPT drives, this is known as the EFI System Partition, or the ESP.
segment.target: On GPT drives, this is known as the EFI System Partition, or the ESP.

segment.source: This partition is usually stored on the primary hard drive.
segment.target: This partition is usually stored on the primary hard drive.

segment.source: The device boots to this partition.
segment.target: The device boots to this partition.

segment.source: The minimum size of this partition is 100 MB, and must be formatted using the FAT32 file format.
segment.target: The minimum size of this partition is 100 MB, and must be formatted using the FAT32 file format.

segment.source: This partition is managed by the operating system, and should not contain any other files, including Windows RE tools.
segment.target: This partition is managed by the operating system, and should not contain any other files, including Windows RE tools.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: For Advanced Format 4K Native drives (4-KB-per-sector) drives, the minimum size is 260 MB, due to a limitation of the FAT32 file format.
segment.target: For Advanced Format 4K Native drives (4-KB-per-sector) drives, the minimum size is 260 MB, due to a limitation of the FAT32 file format.

segment.source: The minimum partition size of FAT32 drives is calculated as sector size (4KB) x 65527 = 256 MB.
segment.target: The minimum partition size of FAT32 drives is calculated as sector size (4KB) x 65527 = 256 MB.

segment.source: Advanced Format 512e drives are not affected by this limitation, because their emulated sector size is 512 bytes.
segment.target: Advanced Format 512e drives are not affected by this limitation, because their emulated sector size is 512 bytes.

segment.source: 512 bytes x 65527 = 32 MB, which is less than the 100 MB minimum size for this partition.
segment.target: 512 bytes x 65527 = 32 MB, which is less than the 100 MB minimum size for this partition.

segment.source: Microsoft® reserved partition (MSR)
segment.target: Microsoft® reserved partition (MSR)

segment.source: Beginning in Windows 10, the size of the MSR is 16 MB.
segment.target: Beginning in Windows 10, the size of the MSR is 16 MB.

segment.source: Add an MSR to each GPT drive to help with partition management.
segment.target: Add an MSR to each GPT drive to help with partition management.

segment.source: The MSR is a reserved partition that does not receive a partition ID.
segment.target: The MSR is a reserved partition that does not receive a partition ID.

segment.source: It cannot store user data.
segment.target: It cannot store user data.

segment.source: Other utility partitions
segment.target: Other utility partitions

segment.source: Any other utility partitions not managed by Windows must be located before the Windows, data, and recovery image partitions.
segment.target: Any other utility partitions not managed by Windows must be located before the Windows, data, and recovery image partitions.

segment.source: This allows end users to perform actions such as resizing the Windows partition without affecting system utilities.
segment.target: This allows end users to perform actions such as resizing the Windows partition without affecting system utilities.

segment.source: Protect end users from accidentally modifying utility partitions by identifying them using a GPT attribute.
segment.target: Protect end users from accidentally modifying utility partitions by identifying them using a GPT attribute.

segment.source: This prevents these partitions from appearing in File Explorer.
segment.target: This prevents these partitions from appearing in File Explorer.

segment.source: To set partitions as utility partitions
segment.target: To set partitions as utility partitions

segment.source: When you are deploying Windows by using the DiskPart tool, use the attributes volume set GPTATTRIBUTEPLATFORMREQUIRED command after you create the partition to identify the partition as a utility partition.
segment.target: When you are deploying Windows by using the DiskPart tool, use the attributes volume set GPTATTRIBUTEPLATFORMREQUIRED command after you create the partition to identify the partition as a utility partition.

segment.source: For more information, see the MSDN topic: PARTITIONINFORMATIONGPT structure.
segment.target: For more information, see the MSDN topic: PARTITIONINFORMATIONGPT structure.

segment.source: To verify that system and utility partitions exist
segment.target: To verify that system and utility partitions exist

segment.source: Click Start, right-click This PC, and then click Manage.
segment.target: Click Start, right-click This PC, and then click Manage.

segment.source: The Computer Management window opens.
segment.target: The Computer Management window opens.

segment.source: Click Disk Management.
segment.target: Click Disk Management.

segment.source: The list of available drives and partitions appears.
segment.target: The list of available drives and partitions appears.

segment.source: In the list of drives and partitions, confirm that the system and utility partitions are present and are not assigned a drive letter.
segment.target: In the list of drives and partitions, confirm that the system and utility partitions are present and are not assigned a drive letter.

segment.source: Windows partition
segment.target: Windows partition

segment.source: The partition must have at least 20 gigabytes (GB) of drive space for 64-bit versions, or 16 GB for 32-bit versions.
segment.target: The partition must have at least 20 gigabytes (GB) of drive space for 64-bit versions, or 16 GB for 32-bit versions.

segment.source: The Windows partition must be formatted using the NTFS file format.
segment.target: The Windows partition must be formatted using the NTFS file format.

segment.source: The Windows partition must have enough 10 GB of free space after the user has completed the Out Of Box Experience (OOBE).
segment.target: The Windows partition must have enough 10 GB of free space after the user has completed the Out Of Box Experience (OOBE).

segment.source: Recovery tools partition
segment.target: Recovery tools partition

segment.source: This partition must be at least 300 MB.
segment.target: This partition must be at least 300 MB.

segment.source: This partition must have enough space for the Windows Recovery Environment tools image (winre.wim, typically between 250-300MB, depending on base language and customizations added), plus enough free space so that the partition can be captured by backup utilities:
segment.target: This partition must have enough space for the Windows Recovery Environment tools image (winre.wim, typically between 250-300MB, depending on base language and customizations added), plus enough free space so that the partition can be captured by backup utilities:

segment.source: If the partition is less than 500 MB, it must have at least 50 MB of free space.
segment.target: If the partition is less than 500 MB, it must have at least 50 MB of free space.

segment.source: If the partition is 500 MB or larger, it must have at least 320 MB of free space.
segment.target: If the partition is 500 MB or larger, it must have at least 320 MB of free space.

segment.source: If the partition is larger than 1 GB, we recommend that it should have at least 1 GB free.
segment.target: If the partition is larger than 1 GB, we recommend that it should have at least 1 GB free.

segment.source: This partition must use the Type ID: DE94BBA4-06D1-4D40-A16A-BFD50179D6AC.
segment.target: This partition must use the Type ID: DE94BBA4-06D1-4D40-A16A-BFD50179D6AC.

segment.source: The recovery tools should be in a separate partition than the Windows partition to support automatic failover and to support booting partitions encrypted with Windows BitLocker Drive Encryption.
segment.target: The recovery tools should be in a separate partition than the Windows partition to support automatic failover and to support booting partitions encrypted with Windows BitLocker Drive Encryption.

segment.source: We recommend that you place this partition immediately after the Windows partition.
segment.target: We recommend that you place this partition immediately after the Windows partition.

segment.source: This allows Windows to modify and recreate the partition later if future updates require a larger recovery image.
segment.target: This allows Windows to modify and recreate the partition later if future updates require a larger recovery image.

segment.source: Data partitions
segment.target: Data partitions

segment.source: The recommended partition layout for Windows 10 does not include data partitions.
segment.target: The recommended partition layout for Windows 10 does not include data partitions.

segment.source: However, if data partitions are required, they should be placed after the Windows RE partition.
segment.target: However, if data partitions are required, they should be placed after the Windows RE partition.

segment.source: This allows future updates to Windows RE to grow the Windows RE partition by shrinking the Windows partition.
segment.target: This allows future updates to Windows RE to grow the Windows RE partition by shrinking the Windows partition.

segment.source: This layout makes it more difficult for end users to remove the data partition and merge the space with the Windows partition.
segment.target: This layout makes it more difficult for end users to remove the data partition and merge the space with the Windows partition.

segment.source: To do so, the Windows RE partition must be moved to the end of the unused space reclaimed from the data partition, so that the Windows partition can be extended.
segment.target: To do so, the Windows RE partition must be moved to the end of the unused space reclaimed from the data partition, so that the Windows partition can be extended.

segment.source: Windows 10 does not include functionality or utility to facilitate this process.
segment.target: Windows 10 does not include functionality or utility to facilitate this process.

segment.source: However, manufacturers can develop and provide such a utility if PCs are shipped with data partitions.
segment.target: However, manufacturers can develop and provide such a utility if PCs are shipped with data partitions.
